timeline.message: Fixes #1050: IndexFunctionHelper.getGroupedKey / getGroupingKey can get array bounds error

timeline.bodyText: Is this required for correctness, or just an optimization?
timeline.author: alecgrieser

replies.bodyText: An optimization, since correctness makes an actual prefix comparison rather more expensive.
replies.author: MMcM

timeline.bodyText: Was the prior behavior here (for nested) that it would just throw an error? I'm not seeing any handling of it at all in the old code.
timeline.author: alecgrieser

replies.bodyText: Prior behavior was it would throw an unsupported error, unless the split happened to be inside the nesting, in which case it would throw an index out of bounds exception.
replies.author: MMcM

timeline.bodyText:
I think this is missing a test that takes a then with a nested and splits it "within the nest". Something like:
concat(nest(a, concat(b, c)), d, nest(e, concat(f, g))
And then splitting it at various points

replies.author: MMcM

timeline.bodyText: Is there a concern that with this change, there will be a behavior change in some kind of incompatible way? E.g., if you had an index defined on concat(nest(a, concat(b, c)), d) with 1 grouping column, and you rely on this incorrectly grouping the expression into nest(a, concat(b, c)) and d? Or will a situation like that have always thrown an error before?
timeline.author: alecgrieser

replies.bodyText: It is a behavior change, yes. If you have concat(nest(a, concat(b, c)), d), that means you're grouping by just a/b.  The previous behavior did have cases like that where it did not throw an exception, but I submit that they returned the wrong answer.
replies.author: MMcM

replies.bodyText: Yeah, I definitely think it was returning the wrong answer, even if it didn't throw an exception. My main concern was If the wrong answer would somehow result in old index entries somehow looking like a corrupt index. Based on the way this function is used, I don't think that's a problem, so I think that this change makes sense (without needing to introduce some compatibility mode to "ask for the buggy behavior").
replies.author: alecgrieser

replies.bodyText: Ah, right, yeah. I don't think these are used where the caller actually evaluates the result, as opposed to lining up meta-data.
replies.author: MMcM

timeline.bodyText: This looks right to me, but I think it could use more coverage on the various cases to validate that
